doc.ContractDescription: IGF::CL,CT::IGF PROCUREMENT OF PROFESSIONAL ACQUISITION SUPPORT SERVICES

GOLDSTEIN AND GALBALLY (2007) ESTIMATE THAT THERE ARE TENS OF THOUSANDS OF DIFFERENT CHEMICAL SPECIES CLASSIFIED AS VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS (VOCS), ALL OF WHICH HAVE VARIOUS IMPACTS ON ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY AND COMPOSITION, INCLUDING A SIGNIFICANT INFLUENCE ON OZONE AND PARTICULATE MATTER CONCENTRATIONS. DIFFERENT VOCS HAVE DIFFERENT EMISSIONS SOURCES, INCLUDING BIOGENIC EMISSIONS FROM PLANTS, ANTHROPOGENIC EMISSIONS, BIOMASS BURNING, AND PLANT DECAY; AND THEIR LIFETIMES RANGE FROM SECONDS TO WEEKS. IN LIGHT OF THE WIDE VARIETY OF PROCESSES THAT CONTROL VOC CONCENTRATIONS, THE GLOBAL INFLUENCE OF VOCS REMAINS UNCERTAIN. CURRENTLY, THE ONLY TWO VOCS WITH STRONG ENOUGH ABSORPTION FEATURES TO OBSERVE FROM SPACE ARE FORMALDEHYDE AND GLYOXAL. IN ADDITION TO BEING DIRECTLY EMITTED INTO THE ATMOSPHERE, BOTH CHEMICALS ARE OXIDATION PRODUCTS OF MANY OTHER VOCS, AND RECENT WORK HAS SHOWN THAT THEIR RELATIVE ABUNDANCES CAN BE A GOOD INDICATOR FOR VOC SPECIATION AND EMISSIONS (KAISER ET AL, 2015). THIS WORK WILL COMBINE THE SATELLITE RECORD OF FORMALDEHYDE AND GLYOXAL WITH A 3D ATMOSPHERIC MODEL AND OTHER AVAILABLE INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION OF EMISSIONS AND CHEMICAL COMPOSITION OF VOCS ACROSS THE GLOBE. A BETTER QUANTIFICATION OF VOC SPECIATION WILL IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR IMPACTS ON ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY AND COMPOSITION. THE USE OF THE EXTENSIVE SATELLITE RECORD OF FORMALDEHYDE AND GLYOXAL FROM THE OMI INSTRUMENT WILL IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE REGIONAL AND GLOBAL EMISSIONS, DISTRIBUTION, AND PARTICULARLY SPECIATION OF VOCS. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION WILL COME FROM OMI NO2 OBSERVATIONS, AND LAND USE AND LAND COVER DATASETS. THESE SATELLITE DATA WILL BE USED TOGETHER WITH A CHEMICAL TRANSPORT MODEL (GEOSCHEM) THAT WILL ASSIST IN UNDERSTANDING THE RELEVANT METEOROLOGICAL, CHEMICAL, AND RADIATIVE PROCESSES. TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE HIGH FIDELITY DATA AVAILABLE FROM NASA WILL ALLOW FOR IN-DEPTH ANALYSIS OF VOCS AND THEIR CHEMICALLY RELEVANT IMPACTS. THE VAST MAJORITY OF THE NECESSARY DATA WILL BE AVAILABLE ONLY DUE TO NASA S UNIQUE CAPABILITIES IN THE STUDY OF THE EARTH-ATMOSPHERE SYSTEM. THE RELEVANT NASA SATELLITE MEASUREMENTS OF ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION WILL INCLUDE OMI FORMALDEHYDE, GLYOXAL, AND NO2 FROM NASA/AURA. THE LAND USE AND LAND COVER DATASETS USED FOR SPATIAL FILTERING OF THE SATELLITE DATA ARE ALL DIRECTLY OBSERVED OR DERIVED FROM VARIOUS NASA OBSERVING SYSTEMS (MODIS, LANDSAT, ETC.), MANY OF WHICH ARE PROCESSED AND MADE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE NASA SOCIOECONOMIC DATA AND APPLICATIONS CENTER (SEDAC). ADDITIONALLY, THE GLOBAL CHEMICAL TRANSPORT MODEL GEOS-CHEM WILL BE DRIVEN BY NASA GEOS-5 METEOROLOGY. THIS WORK ADDRESSES MANY OF THE OVERARCHING SCIENCE GOALS FROM THE SOLICITATION. IT WILL ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE EMISSIONS AND FATE OF ATMOSPHERIC VOCS, AND THE RESULTING IMPACT ON AIR QUALITY, RADIATIVE BALANCE, AND EARTH S CHEMICAL CYCLES. FURTHERMORE, THIS WORK WILL FURTHER THE USE OF EARTH SYSTEM SCIENCE RESEARCH TO INFORM DECISIONS AND PROVIDE BENEFITS TO SOCIETY.
doc.MajorAgency: INVESTIGATING VOC SPECIATION MEASURED FROM SPACE
doc.MajorFundingAgency: INVESTIGATING VOC SPECIATION MEASURED FROM SPACE

doc.ContractDescription: DENDRITIC MICROSTRUCTURES FORMED DURING CASTING, WELDING, AND BRAZING DETERMINE THE PROPERTIES OF COMMERCIAL METALLIC ALLOYS PRODUCED IN NUMEROUS INDUSTRIES, WITH APPLICATIONS RANGING FROM AUTOMOBILE ENGINE PARTS TO AIRCRAFT TURBINE BLADES. MICROGRAVITY EXPERIMENTS PROVIDE A UNIQUE MEANS TO INVESTIGATE MICROSTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT UNDER WELL CONTROLLED CONDITIONS IN A PURELY DIFFUSIVE GROWTH REGIME WITH NEGLIGIBLE CONVECTION IN THE MELT. THIS PROJECT MAKES USE OF STATE OF THE ART NUMERICAL MODELS TO ESTABLISH BENCHMARK COMPARISONS BETWEEN THEORETICAL PREDICTIONS AND MICROGRAVITY EXPERIMENTS CARRIED OUT ABOARD THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION ISS AND SOUNDING ROCKETS. THIS RESEARCH HAS FOR OBJECTIVES TO DERIVE FROM THOSE COMPARISONS FUNDAMENTAL INSIGHTS INTO MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION AND TO ENHANCE THE PREDICTIVE CAPABILITIES OF COMPUTATIONAL MODELING. THE CONTINUATION OF THIS PROJECT OVER THE NEXT 3 YEARS WILL MERGE TWO ONGOING COMPUTATIONAL MODELING EFFORTS. THE FIRST EFFORT FOCUSES ON MODELING DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION EXPERIMENTS IN METALLIC AND CONCENTRATED TRANSPARENT ORGANIC ALLOYS IN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ESA NASA CETSOL 5 PROJECT CARRIED OUT IN COLLABORATION WITH US AND EUROPEAN PARTNERS. THE GENERAL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF COMPLEX PHYSICAL PHENOMENA GOVERNING THE COLUMNAR TO EQUIAXED TRANSITION CET IN ALLOY SOLIDIFICATION AND ITS CONSEQUENCES FOR INDUSTRIAL CASTINGS. THIS PART OF THE RESEARCH BUILDS DIRECTLY ON PROGRESS ACCOMPLISHED DURING THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE CURRENT GRANT. THE SECOND EFFORT FOCUSES ON MODELING DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION EXPERIMENTS IN THE DIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION INSERT DSI OF THE DECLIC FACILITY DEVICE FOR THE STUDY OF CRITICAL LIQUIDS AND CRYSTALLIZATION ONBOARD THE ISS AS PART OF A CNES NASA PROJECT. THOSE EXPERIMENTS VISUALIZE FOR THE FIRST TIME IN DILUTE TRANSPARENT ALLOYS THE SOLID LIQUID INTERFACE EVOLUTION IN THREE DIMENSIONS UNDER DIFFUSIVE GROWTH CONDITIONS. THEY PROVIDE A WEALTH OF NEW OBSERVATIONS TO ELUCIDATE COMPLEX MECHANISMS GOVERNING THE SPATIOTEMPORAL EVOLUTION OF THREE DIMENSIONAL DENDRITIC ARRAY STRUCTURES. THIS PART OF THE RESEARCH BUILDS ON MAJOR PROGRESS ACHIEVED TO DATE IN THE SPADES PROJECT CARRIED OUT IN COLLABORATION WITH COLLABORATORS. BOTH PROJECTS INVESTIGATE BASIC ASPECTS OF DENDRITIC MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION AND ARE HIGHLY SYNERGISTIC. SYNERGISM HAS BEEN INCREASED BY THE ADDITION IN THE CETSOL 5 PROJECT OF STUDIES OF THE TRANSPARENT ALLOY SYSTEM NEOPENTYLGLYCOL D CAMPHOR NPG DC. THIS SYSTEM ADDS THE CAPABILITY TO VISUALIZE BOTH COLUMNAR AND EQUIAXED DENDRITIC GRAIN DEVELOPMENT AND THE CET IN A CONCENTRATED ALLOY REGIME, THEREBY COMPLEMENTING THE DECLIC DSI STUDIES OF COLUMNAR DENDRITES IN DILUTE SCN CAMPHOR ALLOYS. SYNERGISM BETWEEN THOSE PROJECTS ALSO STEMS FROM THE FACT THAT BASIC INSIGHTS INTO DENDRITE MICROSTRUCTURE FORMATION OBTAINED IN THE DECLIC DSI STUDIES ARE DIRECTLY RELEVANT TO UNDERSTANDING AND MODELING THE COLUMNAR TO EQUIAXED TRANSITION.

THE PROPOSAL IS A TWO-YEAR PLAN FOR A MASTERS THESIS RESEARCH AND A THIRD YEAR FOR THE INITIAL STAGE OF A PH.D. STUDY AT UMASS LOWELL. THE NASA MODERN-ERA RETROSPECTIVE ANALYSIS FOR RESEARCH AND APPLICATION (MERRA) DATA, COMBINED WITH OTHER DATASETS, WILL BE USED FOR A LONG-TERM (1979-PRESENT) DAILY WEATHER TYPING ANALYSIS FOR THE NORTHEAST US (HEREAFTER NOTED BY NE). THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED WITH THE HELP OF SOME PROGRAMMING IN MAINLY MATLAB WITH OTHER PROGRAMS BEING USED WHEN NECESSARY. THE PURPOSE IS FIRST TO ANALYZE DAILY WEATHER TYPES (WTS) IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL SEASONS IN THE NE, THEN TO COMBINE WITH THE WINTER WTS WHICH WERE CALCULATED IN A PREVIOUS MASTER THESIS (ROLLER 2014, UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF PROF. QIAN), TO STUDY THE SPATIAL PATTERN AND FREQUENCY OF WTS AND THE SEASONAL TRANSITION OF WTS IN THE NE. THE FIRST TASK IS TO CALCULATE WTS IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL. SINCE THE K-MEANS CLUSTERING METHOD HAS ALREADY BEEN DEVELOPED FOR THE WINTER SEASON, A SIMILAR METHOD WILL BE USED TO CLASSIFY WTS IN THE REMAINING THREE SEASONS. FOR EACH WT, WE WILL ANALYZE ITS MULTI-SCALE CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING SPATIAL PATTERN OF WINDS, PRECIPITATION AND TEMPERATURE AND FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE, DIURNAL CYCLES OF WINDS AND PRECIPITATION, AND PERSISTENCE OR PROGRESSION FROM ONE WT TO ANOTHER. AFTER UNDERSTANDING WTS IN THE FOUR SEASONS, WE WILL CONDUCT A SECOND TASK TO EXAMINE THE TRANSITION FROM SEASON TO SEASON IN TERMS OF THE DAILY WTS. WE WILL EXAMINE THE SIMILARITIES AND DIFFERENCES OF THE WTS BETWEEN SEASONS, AND HOW THE WTS VARY DURING THE ONSET AND DEMISE STAGE OF A SEASON. THE THIRD TASK WILL BE ON CLIMATE TELECONNECTION BETWEEN THE WTS AND LARGE-SCALE REMOTE CLIMATE FACTORS SUCH AS NORTH ATLANTIC OSCILLATION (NAO), ARCTIC OSCILLATION (AO), PACIFIC NORTH AMERICAN (PNA) PATTERN, EL NINO-SOUTHERN OSCILLATION (ENSO), ETC., IN THE SPRING, SUMMER AND FALL, AS WAS DONE IN THE WINTER (ROLLER 2014). UNDERSTANDING OF THE WTS IN ALL FOUR SEASONS WILL GIVE US A HOLISTIC VIEW OF WEATHER AND CLIMATE IN THE NE THROUGHOUT THE WHOLE YEAR. WE BELIEVE THAT THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL PROVIDE NEW KNOWLEDGE IN THE LINKAGE BETWEEN WEATHER AND CLIMATE IN THE NE. WE ALSO EXPECT TO APPLY THE RESULTS OF THIS WEATHER-WITHIN-CLIMATE STUDY IN THE NE ON SOCIETAL AND ECONOMIC APPLICATIONS AFTER THE COMPLETION OF THIS THREE-YEAR RESEARCH. THIS RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE A BETTER OUTLOOK TO THE CLIMATOLOGY OF THE NORTHEAST WITH RESPECT TO PATTERNS OF WTS OVER THE PAST FEW DECADES. THIS CAN HELP DETERMINE WHETHER THERE HAS BEEN CLIMATE VARIABILITY IN THE NORTHEAST, THE CAUSE OF WHICH, IF ANY, CAN BE FURTHER STUDIED.
doc.MajorAgency: DAILY WEATHER TYPES IN FOUR SEASONS IN THE NORTHEA
doc.MajorFundingAgency: DAILY WEATHER TYPES IN FOUR SEASONS IN THE NORTHEA

doc.ContractDescription: IT IS PROPOSED TO EXPERIMENTALLY STUDY THE HIGH PRESSURE HIGH TEMPERATURE PHASES OF HYDROGEN. IN PARTICULAR TO DETERMINE THE PLASMA PHASE TRANSITION (PPT) LINE, A FIRST ORDER LIQUID LIQUID PHASE TRANSITION FROM INSULATING LIQUID MOLECULAR HYDROGEN TO LIQUID ATOMIC METALLIC HYDROGEN. KNOWLEDGE OF THE PPT AND ITS CRITICAL POINT IS VITAL FOR AN UNDERSTANDING OF PLANETARY STRUCTURE AND FORMATION OF GAS GIANTS AND JOVIAN PLANETS. THE LOCATION OF THE PHASE BOUNDARY LINE BETWEEN MOLECULAR AND METALLIC HYDROGEN, AS WELL AS ITS NATURE, A DISCONTINUOUS TRANSITION (PPT) VERSUS A GRADUAL TRANSITION INSIDE THESE JUPITER LIKE PLANETS TREMENDOUSLY AFFECTS DENSITY STRUCTURE, HEAT TRANSPORT, THERMAL EVOLUTION AND COMPOSITION. BY EMPLOYING STATIC HIGH PRESSURE TECHNIQUES, MEASUREMENTS OF THE OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF HYDROGEN WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THE REGION OF THE PHASE DIAGRAM WHERE THE PPT IS PREDICTED. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO MAP THE PHASE LINE OF THE INSULATOR METAL TRANSITION OF HYDROGEN AND DETERMINE ITS CRITICAL POINT AT CONDITIONS SIMILAR TO THOSE THAT EXIST IN GAS GIANTS MANTLES. COMBINING TIME DEPENDENT OPTICAL CHARACTERIZATION TECHNIQUES WITH STATE OF THE ART PULSED LASER HEATING, WE PLAN TO MEASURE CHANGES IN THE OPTICAL PROPERTIES (TRANSMISSION&REFLECTIVITY) OF HOT DENSE HYDROGEN SAMPLES. A SHARP DROP IN TRANSMISSION ALONG WITH A SHARP RISE IN REFLECTIVITY IS A SIGNATURE OF A DISCONTINUOUS TRANSITION, WHILE A GRADUAL CHANGE IS A SIGNATURE OF A CONTINUOUS TRANSITION. THE P T POINT, WHERE THE TRANSITION GOES FROM DISCONTINUOUS TO CONTINUOUS IS THE CRITICAL POINT. THESE MEASUREMENTS WILL LATER BE UTILIZED IN CONJUNCTION WITH AVAILABLE DATA FROM SHOCK MEASUREMENTS TO VALIDATE OR RULE OUT EQUATION OF STATES (EOS) OF HYDROGEN THAT FIT OBSERVATIONAL CONSTRAINTS AND LOCATE THE ORIGIN OF THE MAGNETIC FIELD IN THE MANTLE OF JUPITER&SATURN. AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHASE DIAGRAM HAS IMPLICATIONS FOR GAS GIANTS STRUCTURE AND FORMATION THEORIES AS WELL AS RELEVANCE TO THE GRAVITATIONAL MOMENTS AND MAGNETOSPHERE MEASUREMENTS, EXPECTED BY THE JUNO MISSION.
doc.MajorAgency: THE PLASMA PHASE TRANSITION IN HYDROGEN FOR GAS GI
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE PLASMA PHASE TRANSITION IN HYDROGEN FOR GAS GI
doc.ParentRecipientOrCompanyName: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

doc.ContractDescription: THE HELIOSPHERE SHIELDS AND PROTECTS THE SOLAR SYSTEM FROM THE INTERSTELLAR GALACTIC COSMIC RAYS AND INTERSTELLAR DUST AND GAS. THE CURRENT VOYAGER MEASUREMENTS OF THE PLASMA FLOWS REVEAL THE COMPLEX NATURE OF THE HELIOSHEATH, THE LAST BOUNDARY BETWEEN THE SOLAR SYSTEM AND THE INTERSTELLAR MEDIUM. OUR RESEARCH HOPES TO ANSWER THE QUESTION: CAN WE ACCURATELY MODEL THE FLOWS OBSERVED BY THE VOYAGER SPACECRAFT AND UNDERSTAND THE PHYSICAL NATURE OF THE HELIOSHEATH? WE WILL STUDY THE FLOWS IN THE HELIOSHEATH USING A GLOBAL 3D MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMIC (MHD) MODEL. WE WILL USE A KINETIC DESCRIPTION FOR THE NEUTRAL HYDROGEN STREAMING THROUGH THE HELIOSPHERE, COUPLING A PARTICLE-IN-CELL CODE WITH OUR GLOBAL MHD MODEL. WE WILL STUDY THE EFFECTS OF TIME-DEPENDENT SOLAR WIND IN THE HELIOSHEATH FLOWS USING LY# SCATTERING DATA FROM THE SWAN INSTRUMENT ON SOHO ALONG WITH INTERPLANETARY SCINTILLATIONS DATA, USING THE NEW CODE TO EXTEND OUR PREVIOUS RESULTS (PROVORNIKOVA ET AL. 2014). ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS THAT RECONNECTION HAS ON THE FLOWS BY EXPLORING THE EXISTENCE OF THE INTERCHANGE INSTABILITY IN THE HELIOSHEATH. JUST AS EARTH'S MAGNETOSPHERE PROTECTS THE EARTH FROM CHARGED PARTICLES EMANATING FROM THE SUN, THE HELIOSPHERE PROTECTS THE SOLAR SYSTEM FROM HIGHER-ENERGY PARTICLES IN THE INTERSTELLAR MEDIUM. BY ACCURATELY MODELING THE HELIOSPHERE, WE CAN UNDERSTAND HOW THE HELIOSPHERE WILL CHANGE AND HOW THE EARTH WILL BE IMPACTED WHEN WE ENTER INTO A DIFFERENT CLOUD OF INTERSTELLAR GAS OF VARYING CHARACTERISTICS. RESULTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL HAVE CONSEQUENCES NOT ONLY FOR UNDERSTANDING OUR HELIOSPHERE BUT FOR OTHER ASTROSPHERES AS WELL.
doc.MajorAgency: NASA EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE FELLOWSHIP (NESSF) PR
doc.MajorFundingAgency: NASA EARTH AND SPACE SCIENCE FELLOWSHIP (NESSF) PR

doc.ContractDescription: QUANTIFYING FLOOD RISK FROM CYCLONES IS CHALLENGING BECAUSE INSTRUMENTAL WATER LEVEL RECORDS GENERALLY DO NOT EXTEND FAR ENOUGH BACK IN TIME TO ACCURATELY CHARACTERIZE THE FULL DISTRIBUTION OF POSSIBLE FLOODING SCENARIOS. FURTHERMORE, EARTH'S WARMING CLIMATE WILL CHANGE THESE DISTRIBUTIONS IN THE FUTURE AS SEA LEVEL RISES, STORM CLIMATOLOGY CHANGES, AND SHORELINES EVOLVE. METHODS FOR INCORPORATING THESE IMPACTS, WHICH ARE OFTEN HIGHLY UNCERTAIN, INTO FLOOD FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTIONS ARE THEREFORE GREATLY NEEDED THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES; HOWEVER, THIS PROCESS IS ESPECIALLY DIFFICULT IN REGIONS WHERE EXTRATROPICAL CYCLONES (ETCS) SERVE AS THE DOMINANT MODE OF EXTREME FLOODING BECAUSE RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THEIR SENSITIVITY TO CLIMATE CHANGE. BOSTON, MASSACHUSETTS PROVIDES AN IDEAL SITE FOR ASSESSING THE COMPOUNDING FACTORS IMPACTING PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE FLOODING. ETCS ARE THE PRIMARY CAUSE OF FLOODING FOR THE CITY, AND BOSTON HARBOR IS CURRENTLY SHIELDED BY TWO DYNAMIC BARRIER BEACH SYSTEMS AND OVER THRITY SMALL DRUMLIN ISLANDS. THUS, WE PROPOSE TO IMPROVE FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENT FOR BOSTON BY 1) USING HYDRODYNAMIC SIMULATIONS TO INVESTIGATE A POTENTIAL CHANGE IN ETC CLIMATOLOGY EVIDENCED IN THE CITY'S HISTORICAL WATER LEVEL DATA, 2) FILTERING THE EFFECTS OF MANMADE COASTLINE CHANGE AND MEASUREMENT BIAS FROM HISTORICAL DATA AND COMBINING IT WITH TIDE GAUGE RECORDS TO RECALCULATE AND IMPROVE PRESENT-DAY FLOOD EXCEEDANCE PROBABILITIES, AND 3) INVESTIGATING THE EFFECTS OF PAST AND FUTURE COASTAL GEOMORPHIC CHANGES ON FLOODING FOR THE CITY. THIS RESEARCH WILL USE WIND FIELD DATA, ELEVATION DATA, AND SATELLITE IMAGERY FROM NASA IN ORDER TO IMPROVE PRESENT AND FUTURE FLOOD RISK ASSESSMENTS, ALIGNING WITH TWO OF THE OVERARCHING SCIENCE GOALS OUTLINED IN NASA'S 2014 SCIENCE PLAN: IMPROVE PREDICTION OF EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS AND FURTHER THE USE OF EARTH SCIENCE RESEARCH IN DECISION-MAKING THAT BENEFITS SOCIETY.
doc.MajorAgency: MODELING THE RELATIVE IMPACTS OF CHANGING STORM CL
doc.MajorFundingAgency: MODELING THE RELATIVE IMPACTS OF CHANGING STORM CL

doc.ProductorServiceCode: AC22: R&D- DEFENSE SYSTEM: MISSILE/SPACE SYSTEMS (APPLIED RESEARCH/EXPLORATORY DEVELOPMENT)

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO USE THE SPACE WEATHER MODELING FRAMEWORK SWMF TO STUDY THE STATE OF THE HELIOSPHERE AND THE INTERPLANETARY ENVIRONMENT FOR DIFFERENT STAGES OF THE SUN THROUGH ITS EVOLUTION. THE STUDY WILL INCLUDE: SIMULATING THE STELLAR WINDS OF SOLAR ANALOGS AT DIFFERENT AGES, DRIVEN BY LOW-RESOLUTION MAGNETOGRAMS NOW AVAILABLE FOR SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF STARS; STUDYING YOUNG AND ACTIVE, FAST-ROTATING SUNS, AND EXAMINING THEIR FLARES AND SUPERFLARES BY SIMULATING THEIR CORONAL MASS EJECTIONS CMES; USING BOTH OPTICAL AND X-RAY OBSERVATIONS OF STARS TO CONSTRAIN FLARING RATES; INVESTIGATING OTHER POSSIBLE DYNAMIC MECHANISMS TO TRIGGER SUPERFLARES SUCH AS THE AZIMUTHAL STRETCHING OF CORONAL LOOPS AS THE RESULT OF THE FAST ROTATION; STUDYING THE ROLE OF CMES IN THE SOLAR MASS LOSS RATE OVER TIME POTENTIALLY IMPORTANT FOR THE FAINT YOUNG SUN PARADOX; AND INVESTIGATING THE COSMIC RAY/SEP GENERATION, TRANSPORT, AND MODULATION FOR DIFFERENT AGES OF THE SUN IN QUIESCENT AND SUPERFLARE CONDITIONS. THE END RESULT OF THE PROJECT WILL BE A COMPLETE, PHYSICS-BASED DESCRIPTION OF THE HELIOSPHERE THROUGH TIME AND A GENERAL SCALING OF THE INTERPLANETARY ENVIRONMENT, IN WHICH THE EARTH AND THE OTHER PLANETS WERE FORMED.
doc.MajorAgency: THE HELIOSPHERE IN TIME: SCALING HELIOSPHERIC PARA
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE HELIOSPHERE IN TIME: SCALING HELIOSPHERIC PARA

IGF::CT,CL::IGF ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGY ACQUISITION SUPPORT SERVICES (ETASS 1.90)

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND PHASE SELECTION IN STRUCTURAL ALLOYS AND TO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF CONVECTION ON TIME-DEPENDENT NUCLEATION PHENOMENA DURING RAPID SOLIDIFICATION FROM THE MELT. THIS RESEARCH ADDRESSES FUNDAMENTAL ISSUES RELATING TO RAPID SOLIDIFICATION BEHAVIOR METASTABLE PHASE SELECTION AND ANALYSIS OF THE PROCESSES GOVERNING MICROSTRUCTURAL EVOLUTION.
doc.MajorAgency: ELECTROMAGNETIC LEVITATION FLIGHT SUPPORT FOR TRAN
doc.MajorFundingAgency: ELECTROMAGNETIC LEVITATION FLIGHT SUPPORT FOR TRAN

doc.ContractDescription: OUR PREDICTIONS OF THE FATE OF THE TERRESTRIAL BIOSPHERE ARE LIMITED BY COARSELY DISCRETIZED REPRESENTATIONS OF ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONAL RESPONSES TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. TRAIT-BASED APPROACHES ALLOW REPRESENTATIONS OF CONTINUOUS VARIABILITY IN PLANT FUNCTION. HOWEVER, TEMPORAL PATTERNS OF TRAIT VARIABILITY THROUGH ECOLOGICAL SUCCESSION, INCLUDING THE INFLUENCES OF CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, AND SOIL, ARE POORLY UNDERSTOOD, LARGELY DUE TO THE SPARSITY OF OBSERVATIONS AT THE REQUISITE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO UNDERSTAND THE RECOVERY OF PLANT FUNCTIONAL RESPONSES FOLLOWING DISTURBANCE BY MAPPING FOUR KEY TRAITS--FOLIAR CHLOROPHYLL CONCENTRATION, FOLIAR WATER CONTENT, LEAF MASS PER UNIT AREA (LMA), AND FOLIAR NITROGEN CONCENTRATION (NMASS). THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS GUIDED BY THE FOLLOWING HYPOTHESES: H1. TWO INDEPENDENT PROCESSES CONTROL CANOPY FUNCTION DURING SUCCESSION, RESULTING IN TWO DISTINCT AXES OF FOLIAR TRAIT COVARIANCE: LIGHT AVAILABILITY CONTROLS LMA AND CHLOROPHYLL CONCENTRATION, WHILE WATER AND NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY CONTROL FOLIAR WATER CONTENT AND NMASS. H2. ABIOTIC FACTORS INCLUDING CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, AND SOIL CONDITIONS WILL DIRECTLY INFLUENCE FOLIAR WATER CONTENT AND NMASS, WHILE PATTERNS IN CHLOROPHYLL AND LMA WILL BE INFLUENCED BY STAND AGE, WHICH IS A PROXY FOR STAND STRUCTURE. H3. POST-DISTURBANCE PATTERNS OF CHLOROPHYLL AND LMA WILL BE AFFECTED BY DISTURBANCE SEVERITY AND TYPE DUE TO THE IMMEDIATE EFFECTS ON THE LIGHT ENVIRONMENT, WHILE POST-DISTURBANCE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTIONS OF NMASS AND FOLIAR WATER CONTENT WILL REFLECT PRE-DISTURBANCE VEGETATION. I WILL EVALUATE EACH OF THESE HYPOTHESES THROUGH THE FOLLOWING MAJOR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES, WHICH MAP DIRECTLY ONTO THE RESPECTIVE HYPOTHESES: O1. LEVERAGE THE LANDSAT ARCHIVE, VALIDATED WITH FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND AVIRIS IMAGERY, TO MAP THE POST-DISTURBANCE TRAJECTORIES OF FOLIAR TRAITS IN THE DATA-RICH NORTHERN WISCONSIN HARDWOOD REGION (FIGURE 1). O2. BUILD A HIERARCHICAL BAYESIAN MODEL TO EXPLORE COVARIANCE OF MAPPED TRAITS AND ABIOTIC COVARIATES INCLUDING CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, AND SOIL TYPE. O3. COMPARE TEMPORAL TRAJECTORIES AND EMERGENT SPATIAL PATTERNS OF FOLIAR TRAITS BETWEEN DIFFERENT DISTURBANCE TYPES SUCH AS INSECT INFESTATION, FRAGMENTATION, AND MANAGEMENT.
doc.MajorAgency: TRACKING SUCCESSIONAL DYNAMICS OF FOLIAR TRAITS US
doc.MajorFundingAgency: TRACKING SUCCESSIONAL DYNAMICS OF FOLIAR TRAITS US

doc.ContractDescription: THE CURRENT SCALE OF DEFORESTATION AND THE DEGREE OF DEGRADED FORESTS IN TROPICAL ECOSYSTEMS UNDERSCORE THE URGENT NEED FOR INTERVENTIONS TO RESTORE BIODIVERSITY, ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONING, AND THE SUPPLY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES VITAL TO HUMAN WELL-BEING. REMOTE SENSING HAS ENABLED ECOLOGICAL ASSESSMENTS OF ABRUPT CHANGES IN FOREST COVER LIKE DEFORESTATION, HOWEVER LITTLE HAS BEEN DONE ROBUSTLY TO DIRECTLY QUANTIFY GRADUAL PROCESSES LIKE FOREST DEGRADATION OR AFFORESTATION. FOREST DEGRADATION IS BELIEVED TO BE MORE PERVASIVE IN TROPICAL RURAL FORESTS, PARTICULARLY IN LANDSCAPES AFFECTED BY FRAGMENTATION AND/OR ARMED CONFLICTS. REMOTE SENSING OF FOREST DEGRADATION IS CHALLENGING BECAUSE OF SENSORS SPECTRAL AND RADIOMETRIC LIMITATIONS, INABILITY TO CAPTURE FINE SPATIAL SCALE DEGRADATIONS OR INHERENT COMPLEXITIES IN THE DEFINITIONS OF THE TERM FOREST DEGRADATION . YET, IN SITU DATA THAT GUIDE MAPPING TRENDS IN FOREST COVER ARE BIASED TOWARDS FORESTS ECOLOGICAL PROPERTIES AND OVERLOOK SOCIAL, CONTEXT-SPECIFIC PERCEPTIONS OF FOREST COVER CHANGE SUCH AS DEGRADATION THAT MAY ADDRESS REMOTE SENSING CHALLENGES. AN ADDITIONAL KNOWLEDGE GAP IN REMOTE SENSING OF TROPICAL FOREST IS THE LACK OF DETAILED ASSESSMENTS OF FOREST GAIN DESPITE EVIDENCE THAT SOME TREE SPECIES USED IN REFORESTATION ARE MORE PRONE TO DISTURBANCE OR OFFER LIMITED SOCIO-ECOLOGICAL SERVICES. SUCH DETAILED INFORMATION IS IMPORTANT TO ENSURE ACCURATE MONITORING OF TRENDS IN FOREST COVER AND SUCCESS OF RESTORATION PROJECTS, GROUNDED INTERPRETATIONS OF FOREST COVER MAPS, AND TO LOCATE PRIORITY AREAS FOR FOREST CONSERVATION OR RESTORATION. WITHIN EAST AFRICA, RWANDA IS THE MOST HEAVILY POPULATED, PREDOMINANTLY RURAL COUNTRY AND RANKS FIRST IN ANNUAL FOREST COVER LOSS. THE BIODIVERSITY-RICH, HIGH-ELEVATION WESTERN RWANDA HAS EXPERIENCED UNPRECEDENTED FOREST LOSS AND DEGRADATION IN THE LAST 30 YEARS, RESULTING IN MAJOR LOSSES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT, BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. FOREST LOSS WORSENED DURING THE 1990 S CIVIL WARS AND GENOCIDE WHEN FORESTS SHELTERED BOTH CIVILIANS AND COMBATANTS, OR WERE CLEARED FOR RESETTLING REFUGEES. SINE THE LAST DECADE, NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL INITIATIVES ARE NOW DRIVING FOREST RESTORATION ACTIVITIES AIMING TO RECONNECT REMNANT FRAGMENTS AND IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESILIENCY IN WESTERN RWANDA. THIS HISTORY MAKES WESTERN RWANDA A UNIQUE CASE STUDY TO INVESTIGATE THE LOCATION, SEVERITY AND EXTENT OF CHANGES IN TROPICAL FOREST COVER. THIS STUDY PROPOSES TAKING A MULTIDISCIPLINARY AND MULTISCALE APPROACH, LINKING SATELLITE AND IN SITU DATA TO MAP DEFORESTATION, FOREST DEGRADATION AND AFFORESTATION IN WESTERN RWANDA FROM 1986 TO 2018. SPECIFICALLY, A SPECTRAL LINEAR UNMIXING SUPERVISED CLASSIFICATION WILL BE PERFORMED ON FUSED LANDSAT AND MODIS DATASETS TO MAP TRENDS IN DEFORESTATION AND AFFORESTATION AT 4 YEARS INTERVALS. TWO PROXIES OF FOREST DEGRADATION WILL BE DERIVED FROM: I) TIME SERIES ANALYSIS OF LANDSAT SURFACE TEMPERATURES TO LOCATE TEMPERATURE INCREASES WITHIN FORESTS, AND II) TIME SERIES ANALYSIS OF RADAR IMAGES TO LOCATE DECREASES IN THE STRENGTH OF L BAND BACKSCATTER WAVELENGTH WITHIN FORESTS. IN SITU DATA INCLUDING ECOLOGICAL PLOT SURVEYS AS WELL AS QUALITATIVE SOCIAL DATA COLLECTED THROUGH PARTICIPATORY SKETCH MAPPING, WILL BE USED TO VALIDATE AND/OR IMPROVE REMOTE SENSING PRODUCTS. LASTLY, A MAXIMUM ENTROPY ALGORITHM WILL BE USED TO MODEL SUSTAINABLE FOREST AREAS BY RELATING POTENTIAL FOREST RESTORATION SPECIES TO BIOPHYSICAL VARIABLES DERIVED FORM NASA PRECIPITATION, ELEVATION AND SURFACE TEMPERATURE DATASETS. THIS PROPOSED STUDY WILL PROVIDE WALL TO WALL MAPS NEEDED FOR ACCURATE MONITORING OF TRENDS IN FOREST COVER. IT WILL ALSO MAKE SIGNIFICANT ADVANCES TO NASA S SCIENCE GOALS RELATED TO DETECTING AND PREDICTING CHANGES IN EARTH S ECOLOGICAL AND BIOCHEMICAL CYCLES INCLUDING BIODIVERSITY AND LAND COVER AND WILL FURTHER THE USE OF EARTH SYSTEM SCIENCE RESEARCH TO INFORM DECISIONS AND PROVIDE BENEFITS TO THE SOCIETY.

doc.ContractDescription: OBJECTIVES. NON-NATIVE PINES HAVE BEEN WIDELY INTRODUCED IN THE SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE FOR COMMERCIAL FORESTRY AND IN MANY AREAS, HAVE DISPERSED AWAY FROM PLANTATIONS TO INVADE NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS. A RAPID EXPANSION OF PINE PLANTATIONS HAS OCCURRED SINCE THE MID 1950S GLOBALLY AND ESPECIALLY SINCE THE 1990S IN CHILE, CAUSING EXTENSIVE LAND COVER CONVERSION FROM NATIVE SHRUB AND GRASSLANDS. PINE PLANTATIONS TRANSFORM NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS AND PINE INVASIONS AWAY FROM PLANTATIONS REDUCE WATER AND NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY, DECREASE NATIVE BIODIVERSITY, AND INCREASE FIRE FREQUENCY. THE SPATIAL EXTENT AND DISTRIBUTION OF PINE PLANTATIONS AND ASSOCIATED INVASIONS IN CHILE IS CURRENTLY UNKNOWN. FURTHER, THE ROLE OF ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES IN FACILITATING OR IMPEDING INVASION AT LANDSCAPE SCALES HAS NOT BEEN INVESTIGATED. THIS RESEARCH WILL IDENTIFY THE SPATIAL EXTENTS AND RECENT EXPANSION OF PINE PLANTATIONS IN CHILE, MEASURE PATTERNS OF PINE INVASION INTO SURROUNDING LANDSCAPES AND MODEL PINE INVASION THROUGH TIME. FIRST, I WILL DEVELOP LAND COVER MAPS TO DETERMINE HOW MUCH AND WHAT TYPES OF LAND COVER HAVE BEEN CONVERTED TO PINE PLANTATION IN RECENT DECADES. THEN, BY USING A TIME SERIES OF LANDSAT IMAGES, I WILL QUANTIFY THE RATE AND DIRECTION OF PINE DISPERSAL AT LANDSCAPE SCALES. I WILL THEN IDENTIFY ENVIRONMENTAL CORRELATES TO DISPERSAL (E.G., WIND SPEED AND TOPOGRAPHY) ACROSS A CLIMATIC GRADIENT. FINALLY, I WILL USE THE DERIVED RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AND DISPERSAL TO MODEL PINE INVASION RISK IN CHILE WHERE RECENT INTRODUCTION OF PINES MAKES FUTURE INVASION A PROMINENT CONCERN. METHODS. THIS STUDY WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF UNIQUE CIRCUMSTANCES OF PINE INVASIONS THAT ENABLE REMOTE DETECTION OF TREE COVER CHANGE. FROM AERIAL PHOTOS AND PUBLISHED LITERATURE, I HAVE IDENTIFIED THE LOCATION OF PLANTATIONS AND INVASIONS (I.E., STUDY SITES) IN CHILE. FOR EACH STUDY SITE, I HAVE COLLECTED ONE LANDSAT IMAGE PER FIVE YEARS FOR THE PERIOD OF 1985 TO 2014. MOST PLANTATIONS IN THIS REGION WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE 1990S. THEREFORE, I WILL IDENTIFY THE CURRENT EXTENT OF PINE PLANTATIONS USING A DECISION TREE CLASSIFICATION TO DETECT CONIFERS IN THE EARLIEST AND MOST RECENT LANDSAT IMAGES. THEN, I WILL MODEL PINE INVASION AWAY FROM PLANTATIONS BY MEASURING TREE COVER CHANGE THROUGH THE LANDSAT TIME SERIES WITH RANDOM FOREST CLASSIFICATION. FROM THIS, I WILL MEASURE THE RATE AND DIRECTION OF DISPERSAL OVER TIME. FINALLY, I WILL TEST HOW THE LANDSCAPE (E.G., DISTANCE TO PLANTATION, DISTURBANCE, CLIMATE, TOPOGRAPHY, AND WIND) INFLUENCES THE RATE AND DIRECTION OF PINE INVASION AND USE THE MODELLED RELATIONSHIP TO PREDICT FUTURE INVASION RISK ACROSS THE STUDY REGION. SIGNIFICANCE. PINUS RADIATA AND PINUS CONTORTA ARE AMONG THE MOST PERVASIVE INVASIVE PINES IN THE SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE. PINE INVASION RISK IN CHILE IS ESPECIALLY HIGH BECAUSE OF THE RAPID AND INTENSE INCREASE IN PLANTATION EXTENT IN THE LAST THIRTY YEARS. DESPITE THE RISK, WE LACK A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE EXTENT AND LOCATION OF THE PLANTATIONS AND INVASIONS. FURTHERMORE, IT IS UNKNOWN HOW ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS FACILITATE INVASION AT LANDSCAPE SCALES. CONSISTENT WITH NASA S BASIC SCIENCE GOALS OF DETECT[ING] AND PREDICT[ING] EARTH S ECOLOGICAL CYCLES, INCLUDING LAND COVER AND UNDERSTANDING HOW IS THE EARTH SYSTEM CHANGING, THIS RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP A LAND COVER MAP OF THE CURRENT SPATIAL EXTENT OF ESTABLISHED PINES AND QUANTIFY LAND COVER CHANGE SINCE THE MID-1980S. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH ALSO ADDRESSES NASAS APPLIED SCIENCE GOAL OF ANALYZING ECOSYSTEMS AND ECOLOGICAL FORECASTING, AS IT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF INVASION AT THE LANDSCAPE SCALE AND IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO MODEL INVASION RISK FROM TWO ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES.

doc.ContractDescription: DEVELOPING TECHNIQUES TO IDENTIFY BIOMARKERS IN THE ROCK RECORD IS ESSENTIAL TO UNDERSTANDING PAST AND PRESENT EARTH SURFACE PROCESSES AND REFINING THE SEARCH FOR PAST LIFE ON MARS. IDENTIFYING STABLE ISOTOPE PATTERNS IN MINERALS THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH BIO-MINERALIZATION OR LOCAL BIOLOGIC ACTIVITY IS ONE OF THE WAYS ASTROBIOLOGISTS HAVE APPROACHED THE CHALLENGE OF SEARCHING FOR AND IDENTIFYING LIFE ON OTHER PLANETS [1]. MANGANESE (MN) OXIDES, WHICH ARE PRESENT ON BOTH EARTH AND MARS, HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO FORM ON EARTH VIA BOTH BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC PATHWAYS [2,3,4]. DESPITE LIMITED INVESTIGATION, THE OXYGEN ISOTOPES IN MN OXIDES HAVE BEEN FOUND TO VARY IN A PREDICABLE WAY BASED ON ITS FORMATION PATHWAY AND THE OXYGEN ISOTOPE COMPOSITION OF THE PRECURSOR OXYGEN ATOMS, INCLUDING THE WATER IN WHICH THE MINERAL WAS PRECIPITATED AS WELL AS DISSOLVED OXYGEN IN SOME CASES. HERE WE PROPOSE TO SYSTEMATICALLY INTERROGATE AND CALIBRATE THE OXYGEN STABLE ISOTOPE SIGNATURE IN MN OXIDES THROUGH THE SYNTHESIS AND ISOTOPIC ANALYSIS OF MANGANESE OXIDE MINERALS FORMED VIA CONTROLLED CULTURE EXPERIMENTS AND ABIOTIC REDOX REACTIONS. VALIDATION OF THIS APPROACH WILL BE FURTHER TESTED IN NATURAL MN OXIDE SAMPLES COLLECTED IN VARIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL SETTINGS ON EARTH, INCLUDING MARS-LIKE ANALOGS THAT HOST DESERT VARNISH.
doc.MajorAgency: CALIBRATION AND VALIDATION OF A NOVEL OXYGEN ISOTO

doc.ContractDescription: THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS FUNDING FOR US SCIENTISTS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE 48TH INTERNATIONAL LIEGE COLLOQUIUM ON OCEAN DYNAMICS IN LIEGE, BELGIUM, FROM MAY 23-27, 2016. THE COLLOQUIUM TOPIC IS SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES: MECHANISMS, IMPLICATIONS, AND NEW FRONTIERS. THE COLLOQUIUM WILL PROVIDE A FORUM FOR DISCUSSION OF VARIOUS ASPECTS OF SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES, RANGING FROM THEIR DYNAMICS, THEIR INTERACTION WITH OCEAN PHENOMENA, THEIR IMPLICATIONS FOR TRANSPORT AND ENERGY TRANSFER ACROSS SCALES, AND THEIR ROLE IN PRIMARY PRODUCTION, EXPORT AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL DISTRIBUTIONS. THE REQUESTED FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE A TRAVEL SUBSIDY OF UP TO $2,000 TO 13 US SCIENTISTS, POSTDOCS AND STUDENTS TO TRAVEL TO THE COLLOQUIUM, AND $2,500 TO COVER THE TRAVEL AND REGISTRATION COSTS OF ONE US KEYNOTE SPEAKER. THE SELECTION OF PARTICIPANTS RECEIVING THE SUBSIDY WILL BE BY THE US MEMBERS OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMITTEE IN RESPONSE TO PARTICIPANT APPLICATIONS FOR TRAVEL SUPPORT. THE PARTICIPATION OF US SCIENTISTS IN THIS INTERNATIONAL COLLOQUIUM ON SUBMESOSCALE PROCESSES WILL FOSTER NEW COLLABORATIONS AND CROSSCUTTING THEMES FOR FUTURE RESEARCH.
doc.MajorAgency: PARTICIPATION BY US SCIENTISTS IN THE 48TH INTERNA
